critique: This executive order, issued in 1950, temporarily restricts government appointments to a non-permanent basis due to national defense concerns. It affects civil service appointments, promotions, transfers, and re-employment. It also excludes non-permanent appointees from certain retirement benefits. The order delegates authority to the Civil Service Commission to regulate employee releases and re-employment rights. It does not directly address immigration, social inclusion, or economic regulation. The order appears to expand executive power by granting the President the ability to determine when the restrictions are no longer necessary. It also centralizes authority within the Civil Service Commission. Given the context of the time, the order likely reflects a national security focus related to the Korean War.
